William is a network maintainer now.  would like to see his thoughts on this.

Is this support complicated enough for a design template?

https://openpower.xyz/job/openbmc-repository-ci/30870/ : SUCCESS

Patch Set 2:

(8 comments)

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> William is a network maintainer now.  would like to see his thoughts on this.
> 
> Is this support complicated enough for a design template?

The implementation is little complicated. 
- valid DUIDTypes are vendor, uuid, link-layer, link-layer-time. But, OpenBMC does not support vendor and uuid. We are adding code to display error when these values are specified
- as per the specification, the enum name has an "-" (hyphen). As hyphen is not supported in the enumeration names, the code uses "_" (underscore) to define enums and convents them to "-" (hyphen) while writing to the file.

https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/42508/ : SUCCESS
seems not needed? that should go in the code which implements this interface.

do you need to introduce this error for the ClientIdentifier also?

What are the use cases when this error can be hit?

Though "vendor" and "uuid" are valid enums for DUIDType, they are not support by OpenBMC. Hence, to prevent setting these values, this error is used.

In case of ClientIdentifier, the valid enums are mac, duid, and duid-only and all these types are supported. Hence, there is no need to introduce error.
This takes 3 values. Takes one of "mac", "duid" or "duid-only"

Looks like "duid-only" is back port of "duid" to DHCP4. This is not a RFC compliant.

dhcp4: introduce new option 'duid-only' for ClientIdentifier=

This makes users can configure DHCPv4 client with ClientIdentifier=duid-only.
If set so, then DHCP client sends only DUID as the client identifier.
This may not be RFC compliant, but some setups require this.

MAC ? to match the capitalization of other enumerations e.g.
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/xyz/openbmc_project/Software/Version.interface.yaml#L27 

Or MACAddress maybe ?

As per the specification, the config file understand only these values :
mac, duid, duid-only. As enums does not support "-" (hyphen) in the name, we are forced to use "_" (underscore) for enum names.


https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/networkd.conf.html#
I have renamed it as MACAddress

Should it be DUID to match the capitalization of other enumerations e.g. 
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/xyz/openbmc_project/Software/Version.interface.yaml#L27
As per the specification, the config file understands only "duid". Hence, the enum name is also "duid".
I have renamed it as DUID.
I have changed it to Vendor.

This is uuid. Please refer below.
https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/networkd.conf.html#
My bad. I have updated it.
I have changed it to UUID.
This is link-layer-time and below is link-layer. The difference is '_' and '-'
LinkLayerTime ? I don't see _ in other D-Bus interface names

If the name here is "link-layer-time", then at the time of generating the code from the .yaml file, an enum named link-layer-time is created. As "-" (hypen) is not allowed in the enum name, compilation fails. Hence,the enum is named as "link_layer_time". While updating the config file /etc/systemd/network/00-bmc-eth0.network, it is updated as "link-layer-time"
I have changed it to LinkLayerTime.
I have changed it to LinkLayer.
I don't see underlines in other D-Bus interface names

The enum values are as per the specification. As per the specification, it is  "link-layer-time". As "-" (hyphen) is not allowed in enum value, I have used "_" (underscore).

I understand your concern.DBus interface names follow capitalizing the first char of the word. If it is based on spec, then it is used as such.

Yes, please follow the convention of our DBus apis and convert underscore / hyphenated names to camel case. This is not meant to be directly tied to systemd-networkd even though it happens to be implemented that way right now. I'd prefer not to have any fields that are networkd specific or mostly unused.
I have updated the names as per OpenBMC DBus naming convention.

I believe 'InvalidArgument' can be used for methods.
And 'NotSupported' can be returned for a value which is not supported for the parameter, eg: when user sends in an enum which is not listed in the yaml.

> eg: when user sends in an enum which is not listed in the yaml.

No code should be doing enum parsing directly.  There are sdbusplus methods for reading the enum out of the message.

> I believe 'InvalidArgument' can be used for methods.
> And 'NotSupported' can be returned for a value which is not supported for the parameter,

I'm not sure why InvalidArgument couldn't be used for both.  Why is it valuable to differentiate?  If your expectation _is_ to differentiate we need to document that expectation here so that others continue to follow that convention.  

The fact that we've gone this long without having a 'NotSupported' error for properties tells me others are probably doing something else already.
Yeah. Makes sense. This commit is created ~3 years ago. So, I will remove the 'NotSupported' error
Default is mentioned at line 8. MACAddress
Ack.  I missed it for some reason.

Is there a way the DUID changes can be exposed with a higher level API?
The phosphor-network daemon should be the only entity with detailed knowledge of the DUID configuration.

I bring this up because I am experiencing some pain caused by exposing systemd.network details. This in turn forced D-Bus supplicants to have to duplicate logic that belongs solely to phosphor-network.

The ClientIdentifier is currently set to mac by the default network file. As per https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd.network.html we can enable a system to use duid and other values for ClientIdentifier 

There is no command given to the user to set the ClientIdentifier while enabling the dynamic network. So this change is intended to be used by the system vendor to set the ClientIdentifier to desired value before the box is shipped. I dont think ClientIdentifier should be exposed to any user. This is a personal information of the BMC.

Johnathan - are you saying that this need not be a dbus attribute, instead vendor can directly edit the network files ? I am intending to enable the vendor to use busctl commands in a script to set desired values to dbus, and that can set the network files instead of manually editing the network files. But yes, different feedbacks on this are welcome.

> This in turn forced D-Bus supplicants to have to duplicate logic that belongs solely to phosphor-network.

Can you expand on this with examples?  I don't understand what you're alluding to.

In my early days of IPv6 DHCP work I exposed how systemd.network enables IPv6 Stateful assignment.
In particular I added IPv6AcceptRA to the D-Bus interface. BMCWeb and IPMI both used this D-Bus entry to control DHCPv6.
Fast forward to Oct 2021, where I discover that control is insufficient. To move to Stateless assignment you also need to control another entry in the systemd.network file.
One solution to this is to leak another systemd.network config file element onto D-Bus in order to allow IPMI and Redfish to know how systemd.network sets IPv6 DHCP off, stateful, and stateless.
Another solution, which is what I requested, and merged for D-Bus, is to have a higher level API that allows the busctl/IPMI/Redfish requester to make a "v4v6stateless" request (for example) and have phosphor-network make the appropriate changes to get the NIC operating with a DHCPv4/SLAAC IPv6 address.

The busctl/IPMI/BMCWeb implementers don't need to know anything about the magic puzzle piece combinations of systemd.networkd.

I'm requesting to take some time to determine if there is a higher order D-Bus model that can be created instead of handing out a bunch of puzzle pieces.

Ratan/William - Do you have any views on this from networkd perspective ? 

I believe, we need a dbus property for a network parameter, which is settable/gettable by the user. This is made persistent across the BMC reboot. Editing the network files directly upon the user is not a recommended design of phosphor-networkd.

The default for systemd is 'duid'.  Are we currently actively changing this to MACAddress?  Looks like maybe...

> src/network_config.cpp:                "[DHCP]\nClientIdentifier=mac\n"
Yes, this has been hardcoded into the WriteConfigurationFile function since the phosphor-network inception (22 May 2017).
